comments:
After installing 2.1.1, starting an existing workspace led to this error:

!SESSION
----------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 May 07, 2003 10:26:27.543
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:61)
        at
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:40)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:335)
        at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:291)
        at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:747)
        at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:583)
Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: Fatal Error: Unable to locate
matching org.eclipse.core.runtime plug-in.
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.PlatformConfiguration.locateDefaultPlugins(PlatformConfiguration.java:2264)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.PlatformConfiguration.<init>(PlatformConfiguration.java:903)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.PlatformConfiguration.startup(PlatformConfiguration.java:1368)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.initialize(InternalBootLoader.java:582)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.startup(InternalBootLoader.java:1006)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run(InternalBootLoader.java:838)
        at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:461)
        ... 7 more

Eclipse doesn't start anymore. Removing the .config folder fixes the problem.

There is a similar bugreport for the debian packages (2.1 with the patch from 
bug #36101). Unfortunatelly the whole .metatdata dir was removed shortly after 
this bugrepiort, so I can't say, what the proble was :(

The problem occured for me on WindowsXP. So I believe it is not platform 
specific.

AFAICS, the problem appears if someone defines a new update site (in the 
Install/Update Perspective) prior to the upgrade to the new version (2.1.1). That was 
my case.

I'm pretty sure, that this sin't the case. The mentioned exception is thrown 
before any plugin is actually loaded, so I don't think that update has had a 
chance to choke on something. IMO, this can happen becasue of two reasons:

* The plugin specified in boot.xml is spelled wrong or simple not there.
* the plugin wasn't found in any of the sites

In the case of the debian packages (the error goes away after deleting .
metadata) it's not the first one.

Thats at least my guess after having a closer look into PlatformConfiguration.
java

As far as I know core and update have not yet released any code in the 2.1.1.
stream. Moving to update for further investigation, as this occurs while
processing the configuration and goes away if the configuration is deleted.

The problem which the debian user reported was happening with RC1 and final 
version. Unfortunatelly she deleted the whole .metadata dir. 

http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?archive=no&bug=192176
See also bug #31437

This error is thrown when there is a mismatch between the core.boot,
core.runtime and xerces

Startup goes through a complex algoright to find the bext core.boot, then look
for the boot.xml file to get the best associated runtime and then look into
runtime to find the xerces

Start with -debug it will tell you which Boot is found, look for the boot.xml it
will tell you which runtime is the best... now, the platform.cfg may state this
runtime should not be loaded, in which case update will look at it

I haven't downloaded 2.1.1, but in general we change the version # of boot in
its plugin.cml to notify the update/reconciler a new version of eclipse has been
installed. During this reconciliatio, we compute the 'best core, runtime and
xerces'. We also may have an issue in the recomputation if eclipse 2.1.1 was
installed in the same directory or another

now that I *tried* to explain, do we have a pattern here ? (different location
of install, same ?)

Created an attachment (id=4850)
platform.cfg leading to tthis error

I will attach the platform.cfg of the debian user. I think this is related to 
the 'policy=USER-EXCLUDE' and list.0=[...],plugins/org.eclipse.core.boot_2.1
.0/plugin.xml,[...]

I will attach the platform.cfg of the debian user. I think this is related to 
the 'policy=USER-EXCLUDE' and list.0=[...],plugins/org.eclipse.core.boot_2.1
.0/plugin.xml,[...] 

Putting this into my platform.cfg I get the same error. Good hunting :)

I can see we disabled everything (all the features)
Olivier, did we create new fetaures for 2.1.1 ? if so did we bump the version of
core ? (AFAI can see, core is still 2.1.0 no )

I don't think that has anything to do with that. The two cases I know of happend 
on 2.1.0 versions, one with 'debian only' (first debian version in sid was RC3) 
and the other one with RC1 (normal drop in /usr/local/) and latest debian 
(2.1-4, which is basicly the 2.1 release recompiled from source on debian).

My test case was quite simple.
I used the same workspace for months. It worked great when I ran it with 
Eclipse 2.1 build. When I wanted to switch to the first maintenance build 
2.1.1, I could not restart it without deleting the .config folder. Once it is 
deleted, it can restart. So there is something wrong with the .config contents, 
but the worse problem is that the error dialog is not helpful.

Do you use links/*.links files? The debian packages provide such a file which 
was changed from "path=usr/local/" to "path=r /usr/local/lib" (see bug #36101 
for information why the 'r '...).

Ok , I will check the 2.1.1 drop

My point with feature is that, if we create new feature the reconciler will
disable them upon first restart. So if new 2.1.1 feature are created, and point
to the 2.1.0 core, we will disable core 2.1.0. 

the platform.cfg is a result of the reconciliation and is indeed the cause of
teh 'not found' 
 
Just wanted to know if there was 2.1.1 features when you installed 2.1.1
As I said, I will check into it, delete .config to start properly
Should we close it or is it still happening ?

I do not think it is fixed, since I just saw this bug using build 200310221400 
of 2.1.2. I installed it into the directory where 2.1 had been installed and 
tried pointing it at my existing workspace.

I simply removed platform.cfg and restarted. It regenerated a new one and all is
well. Try it for an easy fix. (save it if it messes you up more.)

This bug is no longer valid in 3.0, as the config data is no longer located in 
the workspace.

causedBy.message: Fatal Error: Unable to locate matching org.eclipse.core.runtime plug-in.
